Diplomacy in the age of 24/7 media? As an eminent Indian diplomat pointed out, from the beginning there was a dispute on whether India or Italy had the jurisdiction to try the marines. Instead of settling this issue through international arbitration based on the law of the seas, the government played into a highly populist line enunciated by the local press and the politicians. Now it is hard to contain the fallout. Once this thing becomes a question of national prestige, the hypernationalistic Indian middle class and TRP hungry news media will blow this issue out of proportion as if this incident was the major injustice happening in the country today.

Very soon there might be calls for declaring war on Italy - expelling the Ambassador is just the beginning. Once the Indian media latches on to a story, beware! All balance or sense of proportion will be discarded - nothing excites the Indian media more than the prospect of a confrontation or a war. Few months back, the Indian media almost singlehandedly declared war on Pakistan because Pakistan has apparently beheaded an Indian soldier in a skirmish on the border. (although Indian soldiers had done the same act in the past and took pride in it). I am waiting to see how the Indian media ratchets up this issue - the most excitable channels like Times Now can barely suppress their excitement! Salvage national prestige....NOW. This is a challenge to India! All Indians have been insulted by this act!

The Indian Government is either naive or complicit. Has it forgotten that it is dealing with a country which chooses between a comedian or a man accused of corruption and molestation? The Italian Ambassador should have been declared persona non grata and kicked out.

I agree it is wrong for the Italian government to not return the marines after giving an undertaking to the Indian judiciary to do so. But...the question of jurisdiction which is fundamental was itself not settled. Did India have the jurisdiction to try the case? In terms of international law, the answer is not clear because this incident did not happen in Indian waters. (as the Indian government was forced to admit  although the Kerala govt. lied initially). When you have a dispute over jurisdiction with an otherwise friendly country, you take it to international arbitration which will proceed according to the Law of the Seas and relevant UN conventions. From the beginning., the Indian media latched on to this case and started extremely belligerent commentary so that the Indian government was goaded into pursuing a confrontationist course. (They were afraid BJP would allege that Congress is soft on Italy). Please look at my other comments. This is not the first time Indian media behaves in this immature way - it happened when they literally launched a campaign of hatred against Australia in 2009. Yes, its a good idea to try a role reversal. Firstly, if this incident happened near Italy and an Indian ship had killed two Italian fishermen as a result of some misunderstanding, the local media and the politicians would not have latched on to this case in this manner and we would not have seen the kind of breathless reporting that we saw in Kerala/India causing the local politicians to rush to take advantage of this situation. In the beginning, India insisted that the incident happened in Indian waters, later the Indian govt had to concede in court that this was a lie - the incident happened in what is called the contiguous zone, not in Indian waters (and according to maritime anaysts no country has exclusive jurisdiction over contiguous zones). Italy offered to conduct a joint investigation which India rejected. Instead of sticking to the specifics of this case and resolving the matter through international arbitration in accordance with the Law of the Seas, the Indian media made it an issue of national prestige thereby needlessly escalating this issue. (and lets admit that in a country where institutions have weak public legitimacy like in India, there is often a tendency to play to the galleries). It was a mistake for the Italian government to not return the marines after giving an undertaking in the courts to do so, but Indian media/society has also failed to display a mature outlook. Other countries will take you more seriously when you behave like an adult.

Imagine if the roles were reversed: Indians on an Indian ship fire and kill Italians in the sea close to Italian territory, are arrested, and allowed to visit India for elections. The Indian state promises they will be returned after the election but reneges on this promise.

In such a case we would call this a rogue act, blatantly illegal and say it reflects poorly on the concerned government. This is what we should be saying about the Italian government right now, that its illegal action makes it a rogue state, and that its credibility in international law has been greatly lowered.

This is not about Indian sovereignty, nor hysterical press, nor "insults to national pride". It is simple: it is about ensuring two poor Indian fishermen killed off the country's coast, receive justice. What is especially reprehensible is that the Italian government appears unconcerned about this. It is hard not to see the Italian action as a racist one: I wonder if they would act this way if the citizens involved was the United States, or the United Kingdom.
